In an address today at George Washington University, President Obama lays out his ideas to rein in federal spending and reduce the debt.
This is just days after a deal to avoid continued - to avoid a government shutdown.

In the speech, the president says we have to live within our means, reduce our deficit and get back on a path that will allow us to pay down our debt, and we have to do it in a way that protects the recovery and protects the investments we need to grow, create jobs and win the future.

The president's address then goes into a lengthy history of, well, how we got to where we are, the ideal of a government that first of all lets its people release their entrepreneurial abilities through low taxes and small government but a government that also, and he quotes here Abraham Lincoln, the first Republican president, he makes a point of saying that, that has joint responsibilities for each other, as well.

And he talks about the balance of those responsibilities throughout our time and then goes through a more detailed history of the late 20th century, of the deals reached by Presidents Reagan and Presidents Clinton to keep the government debt in balance, in control and achieve the balance of - keep the federal debt low.
And here's the thing: I believe that most wealthy Americans would agree with me.
They want to give back to their country, a country that's done so much for them.

Then he points out that, of course, in the previous administration, there were two wars and then the Bush-era tax cuts, tax cuts that he said have not been paid for.
Then the Bush - the wars were not paid for era and also the Medicare Part D, the drug spending program that was not paid for, either.
And then he says he found himself in a serious situation when he came to office.
And now that our economic recovery is gaining strength, Democrats and Republicans must come together and restore the fiscal responsibility that served us so well in the 1990s.
We have to live within our means, we have to reduce our deficit, and we have to get back on a path that will allow us to pay down our debt.
And we have to do it in a way that protects the recovery, protects the investments we need to grow, creates jobs, and helps us win the future.

Or they suggest that we can somehow close our entire deficit by eliminating things like foreign aid, even though foreign aid makes up about one percent of our entire budget.

The president, in a sense, has been referring the debate that has been going on here in Washington the past couple of weeks over the current budget, the 2011 budget, where much of the discussion, indeed all of the discussion, has been focused on about 12 percent of the federal budget; the 12 percent of the federal budget that involves so-called non-defense discretionary spending, programs, well, like agriculture and programs like education and programs like Corporation for Public Broadcasting and Planned Parenthood and other things like that.

It does not involve Medicare and Medicaid.

Those first two, those first three, really, have been identified as the drivers of the spending and the debt.
